;瓦格纳集团的雇佣兵正在完成向俄罗斯军方移交武器的工作，国防部周三表示，此举是在私人军队上个月短暂叛乱挑战克里姆林宫权威之后采取的。

;

;解除瓦格纳的武装反映了当局为化解其构成的威胁所做的努力，也似乎预示着结束该雇佣军组织在乌克兰战场上的行动。

;

;这些行动发生之际，瓦格纳酋长叶夫根尼·普里戈任的命运以及通过特赦他来结束武装叛乱的协议条款仍然存在不确定性和他的雇佣兵以及前往白俄罗斯的许可。

;

;移交的武器包括坦克、火箭发射器、重型火炮和防空系统等 2,000 多件装备，以及超过 2,500 吨的武器。国防部表示，该声明是在克里姆林宫周一承认普里戈任及其 34 名高级官员于 6 月 29 日（即叛乱发生五天后）会见总统弗拉基米尔·普京之后发表的。克里姆林宫发言人德米特里·佩斯科夫表示，瓦格纳的指挥官们向普京宣誓效忠，并表示他们准备好“继续为祖国而战”。

;

;普京表示，瓦格纳的部队必须选择是否与国防部签署合同，移居白俄罗斯或退役。

;

;俄罗斯叛变后，瓦格纳将保留其非洲帝国的一部分

;

;克里姆林宫确认普京会见了普里戈任，普里戈任率领军队向白俄罗斯进军。莫斯科要求推翻该国最高军事领导人，并对结束叛乱的协议提出了新的质疑。

;

;普京在叛乱开始时谴责叛乱行为，并发誓要严厉惩罚那些参与其中的人但作为交易的一部分，针对普里戈任的刑事案件在数小时后被撤销。

;

;与此同时，瓦格纳首席执行官显然仍可能面临财务不当行为或其他指控的起诉。

;

;白俄罗斯总统亚历山大·卢卡申科（Alexander Lukashenko）促成了结束叛变的协议，他上周表示，白俄罗斯向瓦格纳提供了野战营地，但指出普里戈任在俄罗斯，他的部队仍留在自己的营地。

;

;卢卡申科指出，他们在白俄罗斯的部署将取决于普里戈任和俄罗斯政府的决定。

;

;在持续不到24小时的叛乱中，普里戈任的雇佣军迅速席卷了俄罗斯南部城市罗斯托夫。唐并在驱车前往距莫斯科约 200 公里（125 英里）以内的情况下，不费一枪一弹占领了那里的军事总部。

;

;普里戈任将其描述为驱逐军事领导人的“正义游行”，他们要求瓦格纳于 7 月 1 日之前与国防部签署合同。

;

;这次兵变几乎没有遇到抵抗，武装分子击落了至少六架军用直升机和一架指挥所飞机，造成至少 10 名飞行员死亡。协议达成后，普里戈任命令他的部队返回营地。

;

;视频中出现了俄罗斯最高将领，这是瓦格纳叛变以来的首次

;

;叛乱是对普京的最大威胁尽管普里戈任声称起义不是针对总统，而是旨在迫使国防部长谢尔盖·绍伊古和军队总参谋长瓦列里·格拉西莫夫将军下台，但他的权力受到了二十多年的严重削弱。 /p>;

;两人都保住了自己的工作。许多观察家认为，即使普京对他们的表现不满意，普里戈任要求罢免他们也有助于确保他们的工作，因为解雇他们将被视为对瓦格纳老板的让步。

;

;同时谢尔盖·苏罗维金 (Sergei Surovikin) 将军的命运充满不确定性，他是在乌克兰作战的俄罗斯部队的副指挥官，据报道与普里戈任有联系。

;

;自从叛乱开始以来，苏罗维金就再也没有出现过，当时他发帖称一段敦促结束此事的视频，华盛顿的两名知情人士因无权公开讨论此事而要求匿名，他们在 6 月份表示，他已被拘留。几位俄罗斯军事博主也表示，他已被拘留和审问。

;

;俄罗斯议会下院国防事务委员会主席、退役将军安德烈·卡尔塔波洛夫 (Andrei Kartapolov) 周三表示，苏罗维金正在“休息”，并且正在“休息”。 “目前不可用”，但不会详细说明。

;

;在潜在的进口影响下，香港的日本餐厅可能会比疫情期间遭受更严重的损失由于福岛核电站泄漏废水引发争议，一些海鲜被禁售。

;

;周三，该市的餐饮业领导者发出了警告，北角的一名经营者表示，顾客已经被吓到了称情况“比新冠大流行期间政府禁止餐厅用餐时更糟糕”。

;

;香港官员表示，如果日本排放经过处理的废水，该市将针对日本 10 个都道府县实施禁令。福岛核电站流入大海。

;

;预计日本需要 30 年的时间才能处理掉 137 万吨废水，东京方面认为这些废水在经过用于去除放射性物质的过滤系统过程后是安全的。

;

;官方数据显示，去年日本供应了该市约2%的食品，当地消费的所有海鲜中有6.75%来自该国。提供日本商品的企业对禁令的前景表示担忧。

;

;香港日本料理协会主席吴丹尼斯表示，该禁令将对进口商和日本餐馆，特别是提供日本商品的高级餐馆造成严重打击omakase，一种由厨师挑选并采用新鲜食材烹制的菜肴。

;

;如果废水排放，香港将禁止来自日本 10 个县的海鲜

;

;“许多日本进口商食品一直在九州等低风险地区寻找其他供应商，以避开被禁止的地区。运输成本肯定会上升，但这不是最大的问题，”他说。

;

;吴补充说，进口禁令也会削弱人们对日本食品的信心，并引发人们对消费该国产品的担忧。< /p>;

;香港将禁止“大量日本海产品”：李约翰

;

;“这项预防措施向公众传达了一个信息，即日本食品可能不安全。许多顾客可能会在至少半年到九个月的时间里远离日本食品，”他说。 “但是日本餐馆需要支付租金。有些可能无法生存并被迫关闭。影响将是毁灭性的。”

;

;在北角经营寿司店 Hiro Omakase 的 Shadow Cheung 表示，随着 2 月份边境全面重新开放后香港人出国旅游，而当地旅游业尚未恢复，餐饮业已经陷入困境。

;

;香港和东京最近的举措给香港和东京的许多日本餐馆带来了“第二次打击”，她说。

;

;张的餐厅生意兴隆。今年7月，日本透露最早将于8月排放废水。

;

;上周，中国大陆当局表示，将继续禁止从包括福岛县在内的10个日本县进口废水。他们补充说，来自其他地区的所有货物都必须接受全面检查，而不是抽查。

;

;但张表示，有关香港政府周三提出的禁令的长期讨论已经损害了业务.

;

;如果日本释放福岛水，香港可能面临海鲜价格上涨

;

;“尽管放射性水尚未倾倒，禁令也尚未生效，但事实上过去一周当地政府每天都在谈论这个问题，这已经让我们受到了很大的伤害，”她说。 “我可以肯定地告诉你，这比政府在大流行期间禁止餐厅用餐时更糟糕。”该餐厅老板补充说，从其他国家进口原料并不是“严肃”的寿司店的选择，例如她的事。 “这既是对顾客的不尊重，也是对我厨师技艺的浪费，”她说。 “这是令人难以置信的痛苦，因为我们一直做得很好，并得到了很好的评价。”

;

;在佐敦经营一家日本烧烤餐厅的郑伟乐表示，他预计他的场地将迎来超过 30 名客人尽管从泰国和欧洲等地采购原料，但如果禁令继续实施，业务量仍将下降%。

;

;“我知道这一天会到来，所以六个月前我开始使用来自其他国家的供应。但食客仍然会受到心理影响，并且不会相信任何可能从日本获得食材的餐厅，”他说。 “我的生意还没有真正从疫情中恢复过来，但我必须面对另一场危机。”

;

;日本当地超市的一些购物者也告诉《华盛顿邮报》，他们担心食用受污染的食品可能带来的健康问题。

;

;“禁令实施后，我百分百确定不会从日本购买任何海鲜。”房产经纪人许安妮 (Annie Hui) 说道。

;

;这位 40 岁的女士出于健康考虑，他还计划避免光顾日本餐馆，而是购买从阿拉斯加和苏格兰进口的三文鱼。

;

;如果废水处理计划继续实施，“香港人对日本食品的信任度可能会下降”

;<另一位购物者莎朗·张(Sharon Cheung)表示，她已经在避免购买来自日本的生鱼片了。 “核废水一旦泄漏，全世界都会受到影响。我们的健康也是如此。”这位 26 岁的硕士说道。

;

;但一位 60 多岁的陈姓顾客表示，他和妻子经常去日本，并不担心该国释放治疗后的病毒的计划。

;

;“我相信有关核废水排放的国际法规有助于保障日本的水产食品质量。”他补充说，这对夫妇将继续前往日本，品尝当地的海鲜.

; Thu, 13 Jul 2023 10:20:02 +0800 Philippine raid on Chinese firm spotlights human trafficking issues in online gaming industryhttps://www.scmp.com/week-asia/people/article/3227446/philippine-raid-chinese-firm-spotlights-human-trafficking-issues-online-gaming-industry?utm_source=rss_feed

;一家中国经营的赌博公司因员工声称拖欠工资而正在接受调查，卖淫活动和爱情诈骗，此案凸显了菲律宾在线游戏行业的复杂问题。

;

;菲律宾警察部队的 2,000 人团队突击搜查了新创网络科技公司 - 一家大型中国公司 - 6 月 26 日，该公司在马尼拉南部经营在线游戏中心，扣押了据称与该中心内的人口贩运和“爱情骗局”活动有关的计算机数据和保险箱保险库。

;

;超过 2,700 人，其中包括 1,534 名菲律宾人以及1,190名外国人获救。在这些外国人中，604 人来自中国，其余来自远至苏丹和尼日利亚的国家。

;

;五名中国公民被指控犯有人口贩卖罪，并与新创的活动有关。

;

;从马尼拉大都会拉斯皮纳斯市的七座建筑物中救出的受害者人数以及此次袭击的规模是今年迄今为止最大规模，这表明菲律宾如何成为网络犯罪集团的重要活动基地。

;

;该建筑群被当地称为“宏泰”建筑群，内有数千台电脑、近 3,000 名员工和数十个大型保险箱金库。它还包括一家夜总会、一间“浪漫房”和服务式公寓，并配有餐馆和私人游泳池等一系列便利设施。

;

;新创的业务隐藏在深蓝色的带有倒刺的墙壁后面，不向公众公开。

;

;根据资深犯罪记者 Non Alquitran 的说法，三名女性写给小费迪南德·马科斯总统的一封信在促使警方突袭新创方面发挥了作用。

;

;Alquitran，他看到了这封日期为2023年5月25日的信称，这些女性抱怨新创“经理”的“特殊人员”的工资被拖欠了六个月。三人确认这些经理为 Qiuhua Lu、Liangfei Chen 和 Jimmy Lin，并声称新创利用无证工人从事卖淫和人口贩卖活动。

;

;Alquitran 告诉《亚洲周刊》，这封信包含证据和附件

;

;但是接受《亚洲周刊》采访的三名高级警官表示，他们并不知道这些妇女写给小马科斯的信。

;

;警察准将里克莱多·马拉南 (Ricredo Maranan)，该部队公共信息办公室负责人告诉《亚洲周刊》，此次突击搜查是在收到新创员工的投诉后进行的，“有关他们的[拖欠]工资、工作条件以及他们亲眼所见发生的网络犯罪事件”。

;<马拉南表示，6 月 26 日的突袭是“警方的一次常规行动；只是执行搜查令”。

;

;然而，司法部部长耶稣·克里斯平·雷穆拉 (Jesus Crispin Remulla) 对此行动并不满意，他周一抨击警方的行动是“搜集证据”。

;

; p>;

;雷穆拉表示，警方对这五名中国公民“没有立案”，因为“没有具体行为，也没有逮捕他们的具体理由”，并呼吁释放他们。

;

;根据雷穆拉的说法，马拉南周二重申，警方在收到投诉人的证据后进入了新创。

;

;周三，马拉南表示，雷穆拉下令释放的五名被起诉的中国公民仍被警方拘留因为接待他们的律师“仍然没有出现”。只有四名中国大使馆称在中国等待逮捕令的中国公民被移交给移民部门驱逐出境。

;

;新创的律师 Ananias Christian Vargas 本月早些时候表示，一直呼吁释放他的客户该公司是一家获得国家博彩监管机构菲律宾娱乐和博彩公司 (Pagcor) 认可的合法博彩服务提供商。

;

;他后来威胁要对警方采取刑事行动，因为警方拒绝释放他的客户，声称其中一些客户被警察打伤。

;

;马拉南反驳说，由于警方仍在搜查宏泰大院，因此无法释放这些外国人。 “这些都需要搜查令，所以我们必须一一搜查（办公室和计算机）。这就是为什么花了这么长时间。”他说。

;

;领导这次突袭的警察准将 Jack Wanky 表示，仍在对外国人进行分析并向各自的大使馆报告。

;

;“没有尽职尽责”：菲律宾参议员指责监管机构实施网络博彩诈骗

;

;在社交媒体上，菲律宾人对洪泰突击搜查行动仍存在分歧，一些人赞扬警察，另一些人则痛斥警察赶走了中国投资者。< /p>;

;Facebook 上的用户朱莉·黑尔 (Julie Hale) 猛烈抨击了宏泰公司的一位高管，尽管他的活动值得怀疑，但他“不可接触”，而两名自称在突袭期间曾在宏泰大院内的人分享了视频，谴责警方的突袭行动和声称警察的目标是保险箱金库内的钱。

;

;《亚洲周刊》的调查显示，新创过去几个月在 Facebook 上发布招聘广告，提供高薪和其他福利。其 3 月 14 日的广告承诺，菲律宾人的月薪高达 30,000 比索（540 美元），并提供免费餐食和膳食，其他亚洲人和“普通话翻译员”的月薪为 100,000 比索。

;

;6 月 6 日的广告呼吁一位会说英语、懂电脑、女性“垃圾邮件发送者”和“加密货币交易经验”，并承诺月薪 30,000 比索和“高额佣金”。

;

;新创提供的薪资对菲律宾人来说很有吸引力警察反网络犯罪小组发言人、警察队长米歇尔·萨比诺 (Michelle Sabino) 表示，因为“在菲律宾……很难以同样的薪水找到一份体面的工作”。

;

;这并不是第一次博彩中心触犯了法律。 2022年1月14日，警方突击搜查宏泰大院，营救一名名叫毕文琪的中国公民，他据称遭到雇主的人身伤害和拘留。据说毕的雇主向他索要400万比索以换取他的自由。

;

;此案平息下来，目前还不清楚新创是否曾受到调查。

;

;最近的突袭之后7 月 3 日，菲娱乐博彩公司 (Pagcor) 下令新创公司停止运营，并解释为何不应取消其认证，因为有证据表明新创公司“可能参与人口贩运、加密货币和爱情骗局以及其他非法活动”。

;一位年轻的中国母亲捐献骨髓以挽救五名儿童的生命32岁的谭昌是中国东北辽宁省阜新市的一名律师，她在儿子两岁生日那天注册了中国骨髓捐献计划。据澎湃新闻报道，2020年12月8日。

;

;今年1月，她接到电话，告知她已与一名患有不明疾病的小男孩相配。

;

;尽管对捐赠程序感到紧张，但她还是决定帮助他，因为这个男孩与她的儿子几乎同龄。

;

;在捐赠之前，患有严重贫血的谭必须接受服用了六个月的补血药，以满足要求。

;

;“我一直在服用铁补充剂，并注重营养。”

;

;当她准备好捐献时，谭女士说6月30日，她在省会沉阳的一家医院接受了五天的注射，为手术准备血液。

;

;

;

;“不同类型的软对抗持续存在，有些是在外部势力的怂恿下抹黑香港、煽动恶意行动，”半月板顾问刘说。 -中国官方港澳研究会。

;

;“[这些赏金]是对全球的严厉警告，不要以任何形式支持[海外活动人士]，包括财政支持。”

; >;

;香港领导人谴责美国对法官施压，警告持续存在威胁

;

;周二，国家安全警察罕见地带走了前立法会议员罗冠聪的家人进行讯问。< /p>;

;前香港大学（HKU）法学院教授迈克尔·戴维斯（Michael Davis）表示，他相信当局希望阻止活动人士“在香港的事态发展之际揭露香港的事态发展”。试图提升城市形象”。

;

;但现为华盛顿伍德罗·威尔逊国际中心研究员的戴维斯对这一策略提出质疑，称这只会帮助他们获得更多关注，并可能扩大他们的支持基础。

;

;八名被告仍然目中无人，直言不讳，任律师在推特上表示，他因“荣幸地出现在名单上”而“受到热烈祝贺”。

;

;前反对党议员罗是英国国家安全法出台后第一批逃往英国的人之一，两年前获得了难民身份。他的推特粉丝数量迅速增加，最新统计已达到 333,500 人。他最初发布的一条否认共谋指控的推文有 625,600 人观看。

;

;因国家安全问题被悬赏 100 万港元的 8 名香港人是谁？

;

;新一轮逮捕行动警方内部人士称，国安警察上周涉嫌参与支持法律的筹款活动。

;

;这五名嫌疑人隶属于现已解散的民主党众志，被指控与一个组织勾结。外国或外部势力的行为，并实施具有煽动意图的行为。

;

;其中一名被捕者李启庆是一家公司的董事，该公司运营一款名为 Mee 的应用程序，该应用程序列出了所谓的黄色业务对2019年的抗议活动表示同情。上周，该应用程序关闭，其社交媒体帐户也消失了。

;

;长臂管辖权并非独一无二，但未经检验

;

;国家安全法的域外适用一直是争论的焦点。该法第 37 条和第 38 条规定，该法适用于居民和非居民，并涵盖在城市外实施的犯罪行为。

;

;据了解，逃犯最后身在美国、英国、澳大利亚和加拿大。因国安法而暂停与香港的引渡条约，并批评其域外适用。

;

;行政长官李家超上周猛烈抨击这些活动人士，称这些活动人士是“香港的老鼠”。 ”，并敦促八人投降，否则将“每天生活在恐惧之中”。

;

;美国国务院发言人马修·米勒批评该法律的长臂管辖权树立了“一个危险的先例，威胁到全世界人民的人权和基本自由”。英国外交大臣詹姆斯·克莱维利 (James Cleverly) 表示，逮捕令是“中国域外法律威权影响力的又一例证”。

;

;但香港大学法律学者、前英国议会议员陈弘毅教授基本法委员会认为，涵盖严重刑事犯罪的法律具有领土适用性并不罕见。

;

;“美国也因适用域外法律而闻名，”他说。

;

;美国的域外法律文书涵盖广泛领域，从反腐败到反恐，从经济制裁到收集个人数据。

;

;二月初，中国外交部发布了一份报告批评美国扩大长臂管辖权，将其作为“推进霸权外交、追求经济利益”的工具，公然干涉别国内政。

;

;报告将《制裁法》命名为《国防授权法》和《反海外腐败法》(FCPA) 等。

;

;像爱德华·斯诺登这样的举报人在香港仍然有一席之地吗？

;

;本周早些时候，香港前内政部长何志平因在与联合国有关的阴谋中向乍得和乌干达总统行贿而在美国被定罪，他批评美国法律的域外适用。

;

;他在中国大陆媒体发表题为《反海外腐败法（FCPA）：美国的另一条长臂》的文章，称该法是“美国霸权和例外主义的赤裸裸表现”，目的是最大化其经济利益并打压竞争对手。美国公司。

;

;北京颁布的国安法的长臂适用性尚未在香港法院得到检验。

;

;值得关注的案件涉及一名 23 岁的香港人居住在日本的女学生，四月份因在 Facebook 上发布“支持独立的言论”而被捕。她成为第一个在城外因此类行为被捕的人。

;

;袁正廷没有被指控犯有国安法四项罪行中的任何一项，而是被指控煽动叛乱罪。她的辩护律师对法庭上使用该立法提出质疑，认为该立法不包含赋予域外管辖权的条款。

;

;23 岁的香港女性因 Facebook 帖子面临煽动叛乱罪指控

;

;在该市处理与安全有关的犯罪时，使用煽动叛乱法而不是国家安全法已变得很常见。去年，国安警察逮捕了大约 30 人，其中大部分都是以煽动叛乱罪指控的。 Only four of the cases were charged for crimes spelled out in the law: secession, subversion, terrorism and collusion with foreign forces.

;

;National security police have so far arrested 265 people aged 15 to 90 since the law came into force on June 30, 2020. The force said 161 people and five companies had been charged. A total of 79 have been convicted.

;

;A Post analysis of the cases found the government has won every case and the vast majority of procedural decisions.

;

;Nearly four in five of those charged with national security offences have been denied bail, and some have spent more than two years in detention awaiting trial.

;

;They include media typhoon Jimmy Lai Chee-ying, and more than half of the 47 opposition figures who took part in an unofficial primary to improve the camp's chances of seizing control of the Legislative Council. All were arrested in the first year of the law's enactment, with Lai being detained weeks after it came into effect.

;

;Thomas Kellogg, an American legal scholar who researches national security cases in Hong Kong, said the trend reflected a changing phase of the law's application – from reshaping Hong Kong's political and legal institutions in the first two years to a consolidation phase of maintaining the new status quo in the past year.

;

;Offenders convicted of sedition can be punished by a fine of up to HK$5,000 and two years in prison for their first offence. Under the national security law, those convicted can face life imprisonment.

;

;“The security law and sedition are most often used to punish the exercise of basic rights, including free speech, free expression and free association – most of the cases brought thus far would not be considered crimes in other, rights-respecting jurisdiction,” Kellogg, the executive director of the Centre for Asian Law at Georgetown University in the US, said.

;

;“This trend shows that Hong Kong's legal system continues to diverge from its Basic Law roots – the Basic Law human rights provisions simply have not played a role in national security cases thus far.”

;

;Hong Kong woman arrested, 23 detained near park that once hosted June 4 vigil

;

;HKU's Albert Chen said the sedition law “covers a much broader range of speech” than the national security law itself.

;

;“We have yet to see how the higher courts in Hong Kong interpret and delineate the scope of this offence taking into account human rights laws,” he said.

;

;But he said so far the number of ordinary people affected by the national security law “can be regarded as relatively small”. He noted about 100 individuals had been prosecuted for national security offences, if the 47 pro-democracy activists and some other high-profile arrestees were excluded.

;

;Chen also did not see Hong Kong's common law system deteriorating after the security law took effect in the city.

;

;The law had been effective so far in “preventing” crimes, he said, citing the reason China's top legislature, the National People's Congress Standing Committee, gave a month before the law took effect.

;

;The law came into existence to deal decisively with the proliferation of calls for Hong Kong independence and attempts to create chaos, the government has said repeatedly, allegations mostly tied to the 2019 anti-government protests.

;

;Senior Counsel Ronny Tong Ka-wah, an executive councillor, said he expected the number of arrests in connection with the four crimes of the security law would “significantly drop”.

;

;“Most provisions of the national security law targeted deeds or speeches in the 2019 protests. Future arrest numbers will drop significantly as the existing cases already served as a deterrent effect in society,” he said.

;

;A government source said the administration would unlikely use the law readily in future, even as it now had it handy in its legal toolbox. “If we maintain order, there is unlikely to be a need to use the law frequently and we have been restrained,” he said.

;

;'Challenged books' swept off Hong Kong library shelves, but what about shops?

;

;US-China rivalry determines law's application

;

;The coming year will see a number of events and trials that are expected to further shape the implementation of the law. A key one is the legislation of the city's own security law which John Lee pledged to enact “within this year, or next year at the latest”. He had said this was needed to plug “gaps” in the Beijing-imposed one.

;

;Article 23 of the Basic Law, the city's mini-constitution, stipulates that the city government shall enact laws on its own to prohibit seven types of offences. Treason, sedition, theft of state secrets, foreign bodies' conducting political activities in the city, and local bodies establishing ties with foreign bodies are not covered by the existing security law.

;

;Tong expected that during the legislative process, the Crimes Ordinance would also undergo “major amendments” to align with principles of Article 23 and the Beijing-imposed security law.

;

;He expected chapters about treason and offences against the crown might be abolished and that the sedition law could be reformed to keep abreast with societal developments.

;

;Hong Kong's Article 23 'should define state secrets differently from mainland China'

;

;The biggest national security trial involving the group of 47 opposition figures is also likely to proceed through the courts this year. Last month, three national security judges ruled that prosecutors had made a strong enough case against 16 of them who had pleaded not guilty to a charge of conspiring to commit subversion.

;

;Some of those who pleaded guilty, including former lawmaker Au Nok-hin, testified against fellow opposition colleagues during the trial. The court heard Au citing legal scholar Benny Tai Yiu-ting, the architect of the unofficial primary, as saying that having majority control of the legislature was a “constitutional weapon of mass destruction”.

;

;The long-awaited trial of Jimmy Lai is expected to start in September, after it was delayed because he sought to have a UK-based lawyer on his defence team. The Apple Daily newspaper founder faces charges of sedition and conspiracy to collude with foreign forces. He has spent all but eight days behind bars since December 3, 2020.

;

;Hong Kong's High Court rejects bid by Jimmy Lai to drop national security case

;

;Politically, there is a key event to watch in the latter half of the year: whether John Lee, under US sanctions in 2020, can visit San Francisco in November to attend the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (Apec).

;

;Political analyst Lau said the US-China rivalry could influence how hardline Hong Kong, as guided by Beijing officials, would be in handling national security cases, even as it would brook no interference on such matters.

;

;“If Washington continues to contain, isolate Beijing and act hostile in shaping its so-called new world, Beijing has no choice but to firmly defend its core interests,” he said.

;

;The Chinese embassy in Washington issued a statement saying that Xie was invited by Ely Ratner, the US assistant secretary of defence for Indo-Pacific security affairs for a meeting in which the ambassador urged the US side to “remove obstacles and manage differences with concrete actions”.

;

;The statement added that Washington must “prudently handle important issues such as the Taiwan question” in order “to bring state-to-state and [military-to-military] relations back on track”.

;

;Citing a brief statement from US Defence Department spokesperson, Lieutenant Colonel Martin Meiners, Bloomberg and Reuters reported that Xie and Ratner, discussed a “range of international and regional security concerns”.

;

;Ratner emphasised during an exchange lasting about 90 minutes the importance of keeping open lines of military communications between the two countries, which have been virtually non-existent since then-House Speaker Nancy Pelosi's trip to Taiwan last August.

;

;The US Department of Defense did not immediately respond to a request for comment.

;

;The United States has consistently pushed for the resumption of communications, a proposal Beijing has been reluctant to accept. China rejected a meeting requested by US Defence Secretary Lloyd Austin with Chinese Defence Minister Li Shangfu during the Shangri-La Dialogue in June.

;

;Later that month, Secretary of State Antony Blinken mentioned that he had “expressed this concern multiple times” during his visit to Beijing. The Chinese side referred to the resistance in restoring communication channels as a result of the US sanctions.

;

;China may be withholding dialogue as 'bartering chip': US commander

;Li Shangfu was sanctioned by the US in 2018 for his alleged involvement in the procurement of fighter jets and equipment from Rosoboronexport, Russia's leading arms exporter.

;

;Since then, while high-level engagements between US and Chinese officials have made headlines - most recently with US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen's visit to Beijing this past weekend - Biden administration officials had not been optimistic about a resumption of bilateral dialogue on the military front.

;

;Last month, for example, Daniel Kritenbrink, the assistant secretary of state for East Asian and Pacific affairs, cautioned that military-to-military exchanges were not likely to resume any time soon.

;

;China urges US to take 'concrete action' to stop further decline in ties

;

;Re-establishing those has been problematic, Kritenbrink said at the Centre for Strategic and International Studies, because Chinese counterparts “state that they're worried about providing ...assurances that will somehow embolden the United States to take additional actions that they don't want to see”.

;

;Formerly a foreign affairs vice minister for China, Xie was confirmed as the new Chinese ambassador to Washington in May, pledging to enhance exchanges with the US in what he called an “important mission”.

;

;Xie visited US former national security adviser and secretary of state Henry Kissinger days after his arrival in the US to pass on Beijing's congratulations on the elder statesman's 100th birthday.

;The World Health Organization warned Wednesday that the recent surge in bird flu outbreaks among mammals could help the virus spread more easily among humans.

;

;Since late 2021, Europe has been gripped by its worst-ever outbreak of bird flu, while North and South America have also experienced severe outbreaks.

;

;This has led to the culling of tens of millions of poultry worldwide, many with the H5N1 strain of the virus, which first emerged in 1996.

;

;But there has recently been a worrying spike in infections in mammals.

;

;“Avian influenza viruses normally spread among birds, but the increasing number of H5N1 avian influenza detections among mammals – which are biologically closer to humans than birds are – raises concern that the virus might adapt to infect humans more easily,” the WHO said in a statement.

;

;“In addition, some mammals may act as mixing vessels for influenza viruses, leading to the emergence of new viruses that could be more harmful to animals and humans.”

;

;Outbreaks have been reported in 26 species, including farmed mink in Spain and sea lions in Chile. H5N1 was recently detected in cats in Poland.

;

;The WHO, along with the UN's Food and Agriculture Organisation (FAO) and the World Organisation for Animal Health (WOAH), urged countries to work together to save animals and protect people.

;

;“There is a recent paradigm change in the ecology and epidemiology of avian influenza which has heightened global concern as the disease spread to new geographical regions and caused unusual wild bird die-offs, and alarming rise in mammalian cases,” said WOAH science chief Gregorio Torres.

;

;Chinese woman dies of H3N8, marking first human fatality from bird flu strain

;

;Infections in humans can cause severe disease with a high mortality rate. Human bird flu cases are usually the result of direct or indirect exposure to infected live or dead poultry or contaminated environments.

;

;“The virus does not appear to be able to transmit from one person to another easily, but vigilance is needed to identify any evolution in the virus that can change that,” said the WHO's pandemic preparedness chief Sylvie Briand.

;

;Experts were looking for changes that could be more dangerous to humans, and urged countries to boost their monitoring capabilities, she added.

;

;“This is especially important as the virus is now affecting countries with limited prior experience in avian-flu surveillance,” Briand said.

;

;The WHO said that since 2020, a variant had led to an “unprecedented” number of deaths in wild birds and poultry in many countries in Africa, Asia and Europe. The virus spread to North America in 2021 and then to Central and South America in 2022.

;

;Last year, 67 countries in five continents reported highly pathogenic H5N1 bird flu outbreaks, with more than 131 million domestic poultry lost due to death or culling in affected farms and villages.

;

;In 2023, another 14 countries reported outbreaks, mainly in the Americas, as the disease continues to spread.

;

;These outbreaks have caused “devastation” in poultry and had harmed farmers' livelihoods and the food trade, the WHO said.

;

;Japan farmers urged not to crack from stress of bird flu crisis, egg shortages

;

;“Several mass death events have been reported in wild birds,” the UN health agency added.

;

;“Although largely affecting animals, these outbreaks pose ongoing risks to humans,” it said.

;

;“The epidemiology of H5N1 continues to rapidly evolve,” said the FAO's chief veterinary officer Keith Sumption.

;

;He pleaded for timely sharing of genetic sequences to monitor for changes, resulting in better risk assessment and disease control.

;Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi heads to France on Thursday to deepen ties with New Delhi's oldest strategic partner in the West, with a slew of high-profile defence deals expected and a new joint plan to ensure stability in the Indo-Pacific.

;

;Modi has been invited as the guest of honour at the Bastille Day celebrations by French President Emmanuel Macron. Units from India's army, navy and air force will also participate in the parade, including two of the 36 Rafale fighter jets India bought in 2015 for nearly US$9 billion.

;

;The visit will “provide an opportunity to chart the course of the partnership for the future across diverse sectors such as strategic, cultural, scientific, academic and economic cooperation,” the Indian government said in a statement on Wednesday.

;

;This year marks 25th anniversary of the strategic partnership between the two countries, and the announcement of the new military deals will burnish the deepening defence ties between the two nations.

;

;What new defence, tech deals could mean for India-US ties amid China tensions

;

;France has been one of India's closest partners in Europe for decades. Paris was the only Western capital to not impose sanctions on New Delhi after India conducted nuclear tests in 1998.

;

;Ten years later, when India got Nuclear Suppliers Group waiver for its civil nuclear plans, France was the first country to sign an agreement.

;

;India has relied on French fighter jets for four decades now. Much before buying Dassault Aviation's Rafale in 2015, India bought Mirage jets in 1980s, which still comprise two squadrons of the air force.

;

;In 2005, India bought six Scorpene-class diesel submarines from France for 188 billion rupees (US$2.28 billion) to be built in India by Mazagon Dock Shipbuilders (MDL) in partnership with the French Naval Group, the last of which will be commissioned next year.

;

;The ageing fleet of India's Russian-made platforms, Moscow's inability to perform maintenance work, and delays in India's indigenous manufacturing plans for parallel platforms have necessitated the two new defence deals.

;

;For submarines, India is expected to buy three more Scorpene submarines, which will again be made by MDL and the Naval group, government sources in New Delhi and Paris said. The price of the deals has yet to be agreed.

;

;India is also expected to agree to buy 26 Rafale jets, the sources said, without giving the deal's expected value.

;

;The marine version of Dassualt's Rafale jets, intended for India's first indigenous aircraft carrier commissioned in August 2022, outperformed the American SuperhornetF18s in tests last year for Indian requirements.

;

;During the visit, Macron will host Modi for a private dinner, as well as a state banquet at the Louvre Museum. Modi will also meet other political leaders, selected French personalities and business leaders, and interact with the Indian diaspora.

;

;Both India and France through its island territories have deep interests in the Indian Ocean and are concerned about China's growing assertiveness in the region. Details of an announcement on a plan for the region are not known.

;

;Can India be 'Global South champion' amid US-China rivalry in the Pacific?

;

;The visit comes less than a month after President Joe Biden hosted Modi for a state visit, during which the US offered critical military technology including fighter jet engines and high altitude drones to India.

;

;Last week Modi chaired an online meeting of leaders of the Shanghai Cooperation Group members, which included Russian President Vladimir Putin and China's Xi Jinping.

;

;Macron, Biden, Putin and Xi, along with leaders of the other G20 members countries are expected to visit New Delhi in September for its summit to be hosted by India as its head this year.

;

;The Indian leader will also later visit the UAE and meet President Sheikh Mohamed bin Zayed Al Nahyan, who is also the ruler of Abu Dhabi.

; Thu, 13 Jul 2023 07:20:02 +0800 To the moon and back: China reveals first details of crewed lunar landing mission by 2030https://www.scmp.com/news/china/science/article/3227448/moon-and-back-china-reveals-first-details-crewed-lunar-landing-mission-2030?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.07.13 06:00;
;;

;China has for the first time unveiled details of its plans to land astronauts on the Moon by the end of the decade.

;

;If successful, the mission would make China only the second country after the United States to have achieved the feat.

;

;China will use the lunar orbit rendezvous (LOR) process for the mission, state media reported, citing a senior engineer at the national space agency.

;

;The Chinese LOR process will be similar to that adopted by the US Apollo programme more than half a century ago.

;

;But unlike the Apollo mission, which used one rocket to carry both the moon lander and the command spaceship into lunar orbit, China will be sending them aboard two separate rockets.

;

;Zhang Hailian, deputy chief engineer at the China Manned Space Agency's Engineering Office, said the lunar lander and crewed spacecraft would be sent separately for rendezvous and docking in orbit, state broadcaster CCTV reported on Wednesday.

;

;The astronauts will then move from the command spacecraft into the moon lander and descend to the lunar surface, Zhang was quoted as telling a space forum in China's central city of Wuhan.

;

;After carrying out scientific investigations and sample collection, the crew will board the lander again to ascend to lunar orbit, where they will rendezvous and dock with the command spacecraft for the return journey to Earth, Zhang said.

;

;Chinese researchers are developing the Long March 10 heavy carrier rocket, a new generation of manned spacecraft, a lunar lander and a crewed lunar rover for the mission, he added.

;

;The process described by Zhang in a presentation to the forum was largely expected, after being adopted by the Apollo programme in the 1960s and 1970s, as it is the most economical way to send humans on a round-trip to the Moon.

;

;The process allows for maximum payload saving, as the bigger command and service spaceship remains in orbit, and only needs to carry fuel for the lightweight lunar lander's descent and ascent.

;

;The Apollo astronauts separated the spacecraft from the powerful Saturn V rocket after entering the moon's trajectory, and then travelled on it for three days until they reached lunar orbit. But China's process would see the spacecraft and the lander enter the lunar orbit directly on board their respective rockets.

;

;In both processes, after completing the lunar mission, the lander is discarded following the transfer of crew and payload.

;

;Apart from repeating China's plans to land a crew on the moon before 2030, Zhang also underlined its aim to set up a research station to conduct “systematic and continuous lunar exploration and related technology [tests]”.

;

;China unveils construction road map for lunar research station

;

;The Chinese space agency is collaborating with Russia's Roscosmos to build a joint moon base by the mid-2030s.

;

;A moon landing concept picture presented in December by Wu Yansheng, chairman of the China Aerospace Science and Technology Corporation, the country's main space contractor and builder of rockets including the Long March series, showed China was likely to send three astronauts for the moon-landing mission.

;

;Two of them are likely to travel on the lander to set foot on the moon, while the third would be piloting the command and service spaceship in lunar orbit, the picture suggested.

;

;China has made major progress in its moon probes since launching its first orbiter, the Chang'e 1, in 2007. The latest in the series, Chang'e 5, was launched in November 2020. It landed a rover on the moon on December 1 that year and returned to Earth with 2kg (4.6lb) of lunar soil two weeks later.

;

;The US also aims to restart crewed moon missions to the moon this decade under Nasa's Artemis programme, which would be its first lunar landing since 1972, and is also planning for a crewed mission to Mars.

;A Southeast Asian LGBTQ event set to be held in Indonesia next week has been cancelled and relocated after a series of security threats, organisers said in a statement.

;

;Homosexuality is legal everywhere in Indonesia except in conservative Aceh province, which adheres to strict Islamic laws, but gay couples often face discrimination in the world's most populous Muslim-majority country.

;

;Asean Queer Advocacy Week was set to be held in the capital Jakarta from July 17 to 21, bringing together LGBTQ activists from around the region to connect and discuss challenges to the community.

;

;In Indonesia, 'LGBT' label is linked to criminality amid 'societal homophobia'

;

;“The organisers of the Asean Queer Advocacy Week decided to relocate the venue of the programme outside Indonesia, after receiving a series of security threats from various groups,” Philippines-based organiser Asean SOGIE Caucus said in a statement late on Tuesday.

;

;“The decision was made to ensure the safety and security of both the participants and the organiser.”

;

;Asean SOGIE Caucus, which organised the event with Indonesian group Arus Pelangi and Thailand's Asian Forum for Human Rights and Development, said it had been monitoring a “wave of 'anti-LGBT' sentiment on social media”.

;

;They did not say when or where the relocated event would take place for security reasons.

;

;Will a video about 'being gay in Indonesia' lead to an anti-LGBT law?

;

;The Southeast Asian country's most powerful Islamic regulatory body, the Indonesian Ulema Council, called on the government to prevent the meeting from being held in Indonesia.

;

;“The government should not give a permit to any event in this country that contradicts religious values,” the council's deputy chairman Anwar Abbas said in a statement.

;

;He said none of the six officially recognised religions in Indonesia “tolerates LGBT practices”.

;

;Other LGBTQ events have been cancelled in Indonesia after resistance from Islamic groups in recent years, including a visit by US special LGBTQ envoy Jessica Stern in December.

;

;Outside Aceh, Indonesia's current laws on homosexuality are, however, more liberal than some of its neighbours.

;

;Sodomy is a criminal offence in Malaysia and can result in imprisonment, corporal punishment, and fines.

;

;Conversely in Singapore, gay sex was decriminalised last year.
